frontmatter.title: Perturbation of the larger chain complex in a chain reduction

mainmatter.p: Given a reduction \rho : C \Rightarrow \mkern {-14mu} \Rightarrow Dρ:C⇒⇒D\rho : C \Rightarrow \mkern {-14mu} \Rightarrow Dρ:C⇒⇒D and a perturbation \delta _CδC\delta _CδC​ for CCCC, we assume that h_{ \rho } \circ \delta _Chρ∘δCh_{ \rho } \circ \delta _Chρ​∘δC​ is pointwise nilpotent, i.e. \forall c \in C_k, \exists n \in \mathbb {N}, \; ( h_{ \rho } \delta _C)^n (c) = 0.∀c∈Ck,∃n∈N,  (hρδC)n(c)=0.\forall c \in C_k, \exists n \in \mathbb {N}, \; ( h_{ \rho } \delta _C)^n (c) = 0.∀c∈Ck​,∃n∈N,(hρ​δC​)n(c)=0. We can construct a new chain reduction \rho ' : C' \Rightarrow \mkern {-14mu} \Rightarrow D'ρ′:C′⇒⇒D′\rho ' : C' \Rightarrow \mkern {-14mu} \Rightarrow D'ρ′:C′⇒⇒D′, where C'C′C'C′ is CCCC perturbed by \delta _CδC\delta _CδC​.
Note that this situation is much harder compared to , as it is generally impossible without the added condition.

For this construction using the third equivalent definition of a chain reduction in , i.e. a homotopy operator on CCCC such that h \circ h = 0h∘h=0h \circ h = 0h∘h=0 and h \circ d_C \circ h = hh∘dC∘h=hh \circ d_C \circ h = hh∘dC​∘h=h.

We need to construct a new homotopy operator such that h' \circ h' = 0h′∘h′=0h' \circ h' = 0h′∘h′=0 and h' \circ (d_C + \delta _C) \circ h' = h'h′∘(dC+δC)∘h′=h′h' \circ (d_C + \delta _C) \circ h' = h'h′∘(dC​+δC​)∘h′=h′. We approach this through a “perturbative” mindset. Starting with h_0 = hh0=hh_0 = hh0​=h, the second equation is off by a difference of h_0 \delta _C h_0h0δCh0h_0 \delta _C h_0h0​δC​h0​. We simply add this as a correction term, h_1 = h_0 + \alpha h_0 \delta _C h_0h1=h0+αh0δCh0h_1 = h_0 + \alpha h_0 \delta _C h_0h1​=h0​+αh0​δC​h0​ where \alphaα\alphaα is some coefficient. (Note that essentially the only terms we can consider are of the form h_0 \delta _C h_0 \delta _C \cdots h_0h0δCh0δC⋯h0h_0 \delta _C h_0 \delta _C \cdots h_0h0​δC​h0​δC​⋯h0​, since nothing else has the same type.) We still have h_1 \circ h_1 = 0h1∘h1=0h_1 \circ h_1 = 0h1​∘h1​=0, and for the second equation this creates a new error term \begin {aligned} & \quad h_1 (d_C + \delta _C) h_1 - h_1 \\ &= (1 + \alpha ) h_0 \delta _C h_0 + 2 ( \alpha + \alpha ^2) h_0 \delta _C h_0 \delta _C h_0 + \alpha ^2 h_0 \delta _C h_0 \delta _C h_0 \delta _C h_0 \end {aligned}h1(dC+δC)h1−h1=(1+α)h0δCh0+2(α+α2)h0δCh0δCh0+α2h0δCh0δCh0δCh0\begin {aligned} & \quad h_1 (d_C + \delta _C) h_1 - h_1 \\ &= (1 + \alpha ) h_0 \delta _C h_0 + 2 ( \alpha + \alpha ^2) h_0 \delta _C h_0 \delta _C h_0 + \alpha ^2 h_0 \delta _C h_0 \delta _C h_0 \delta _C h_0 \end {aligned}​h1​(dC​+δC​)h1​−h1​=(1+α)h0​δC​h0​+2(α+α2)h0​δC​h0​δC​h0​+α2h0​δC​h0​δC​h0​δC​h0​​ and we can eliminate the first and second order part by setting \alpha = -1α=−1\alpha = -1α=−1. The natural next step would be to add a further correction h_2 = h_1 + \beta h_0 \delta _C h_0 \delta _C h_0h2=h1+βh0δCh0δCh0h_2 = h_1 + \beta h_0 \delta _C h_0 \delta _C h_0h2​=h1​+βh0​δC​h0​δC​h0​. This turns out to require \beta = +1β=+1\beta = +1β=+1, and so on.

From the informal discussion above, we can conjecture the formula h' = \sum _{k=0}^ \infty (-1)^k (h \delta _C)^k h.h′=∑k=0∞(−1)k(hδC)kh.h' = \sum _{k=0}^ \infty (-1)^k (h \delta _C)^k h.h′=k=0∑∞​(−1)k(hδC​)kh. This reveals the reason for our pointwise nilpotency condition. With a little bit of care manipulating the infinite sum, we can prove that h' \circ h' = 0h′∘h′=0h' \circ h' = 0h′∘h′=0 from h \circ h = 0h∘h=0h \circ h = 0h∘h=0, and the second equation follows from a nice telescopic sum \begin {aligned} h' \circ (d_C + \delta _C) \circ h' &= \sum _{i, j} (-1)^{i + j} (h \delta _C)^i h (d_C + \delta _C) (h \delta _C)^j h \\ &= \sum _{i, j} (-1)^{i + j} \left [(h \delta _C)^{i + j + 1} h + (h \delta _C)^{i + j} h \right ] \\ &= \sum _{k} (k+1) (-1)^k \left [(h \delta _C)^{k + 1} h + (h \delta _C)^k h \right ] \\ &= \sum _k (-1)^k (h \delta _C)^k h = h'. \end {aligned}h′∘(dC+δC)∘h′=∑i,j(−1)i+j(hδC)ih(dC+δC)(hδC)jh=∑i,j(−1)i+j[(hδC)i+j+1h+(hδC)i+jh]=∑k(k+1)(−1)k[(hδC)k+1h+(hδC)kh]=∑k(−1)k(hδC)kh=h′.\begin {aligned} h' \circ (d_C + \delta _C) \circ h' &= \sum _{i, j} (-1)^{i + j} (h \delta _C)^i h (d_C + \delta _C) (h \delta _C)^j h \\ &= \sum _{i, j} (-1)^{i + j} \left [(h \delta _C)^{i + j + 1} h + (h \delta _C)^{i + j} h \right ] \\ &= \sum _{k} (k+1) (-1)^k \left [(h \delta _C)^{k + 1} h + (h \delta _C)^k h \right ] \\ &= \sum _k (-1)^k (h \delta _C)^k h = h'. \end {aligned}h′∘(dC​+δC​)∘h′​=i,j∑​(−1)i+j(hδC​)ih(dC​+δC​)(hδC​)jh=i,j∑​(−1)i+j[(hδC​)i+j+1h+(hδC​)i+jh]=k∑​(k+1)(−1)k[(hδC​)k+1h+(hδC​)kh]=k∑​(−1)k(hδC​)kh=h′.​

We can reconstruct the other two components of the reduction \iota _{ \rho ' }ιρ′\iota _{ \rho ' }ιρ′​ and \pi _{ \rho ' }πρ′\pi _{ \rho ' }πρ′​ through . In particular, D'D′D'D′ is given by a perturbation of DDDD. We only write down the results below for easy reference. \begin {aligned} \pi _{ \rho ' } &= \sum _{k=0}^ \infty (-1)^k \pi _{ \rho } ( \delta _C h_{ \rho } )^k \\ \iota _{ \rho ' } &= \sum _{k=0}^ \infty (-1)^k ( h_{ \rho } \delta _C)^k \iota _{ \rho } \\ \delta _D &= \sum _{k=0}^ \infty (-1)^k \pi _{ \rho } \delta _C ( h_{ \rho } \delta _C)^k \iota _{ \rho } . \end {aligned}πρ′=∑k=0∞(−1)kπρ(δChρ)kιρ′=∑k=0∞(−1)k(hρδC)kιρδD=∑k=0∞(−1)kπρδC(hρδC)kιρ.\begin {aligned} \pi _{ \rho ' } &= \sum _{k=0}^ \infty (-1)^k \pi _{ \rho } ( \delta _C h_{ \rho } )^k \\ \iota _{ \rho ' } &= \sum _{k=0}^ \infty (-1)^k ( h_{ \rho } \delta _C)^k \iota _{ \rho } \\ \delta _D &= \sum _{k=0}^ \infty (-1)^k \pi _{ \rho } \delta _C ( h_{ \rho } \delta _C)^k \iota _{ \rho } . \end {aligned}πρ′​ιρ′​δD​​=k=0∑∞​(−1)kπρ​(δC​hρ​)k=k=0∑∞​(−1)k(hρ​δC​)kιρ​=k=0∑∞​(−1)kπρ​δC​(hρ​δC​)kιρ​.​

frontmatter.title: Perturbation of the larger chain complex in a chain reduction

mainmatter.p: Given a reduction \rho : C \Rightarrow \mkern {-14mu} \Rightarrow Dρ:C⇒⇒D\rho : C \Rightarrow \mkern {-14mu} \Rightarrow Dρ:C⇒⇒D and a perturbation \delta _CδC\delta _CδC​ for CCCC, we assume that h_{ \rho } \circ \delta _Chρ∘δCh_{ \rho } \circ \delta _Chρ​∘δC​ is pointwise nilpotent, i.e. \forall c \in C_k, \exists n \in \mathbb {N}, \; ( h_{ \rho } \delta _C)^n (c) = 0.∀c∈Ck,∃n∈N,  (hρδC)n(c)=0.\forall c \in C_k, \exists n \in \mathbb {N}, \; ( h_{ \rho } \delta _C)^n (c) = 0.∀c∈Ck​,∃n∈N,(hρ​δC​)n(c)=0. We can construct a new chain reduction \rho ' : C' \Rightarrow \mkern {-14mu} \Rightarrow D'ρ′:C′⇒⇒D′\rho ' : C' \Rightarrow \mkern {-14mu} \Rightarrow D'ρ′:C′⇒⇒D′, where C'C′C'C′ is CCCC perturbed by \delta _CδC\delta _CδC​.
Note that this situation is much harder compared to , as it is generally impossible without the added condition.

For this construction using the third equivalent definition of a chain reduction in , i.e. a homotopy operator on CCCC such that h \circ h = 0h∘h=0h \circ h = 0h∘h=0 and h \circ d_C \circ h = hh∘dC∘h=hh \circ d_C \circ h = hh∘dC​∘h=h.

We need to construct a new homotopy operator such that h' \circ h' = 0h′∘h′=0h' \circ h' = 0h′∘h′=0 and h' \circ (d_C + \delta _C) \circ h' = h'h′∘(dC+δC)∘h′=h′h' \circ (d_C + \delta _C) \circ h' = h'h′∘(dC​+δC​)∘h′=h′. We approach this through a “perturbative” mindset. Starting with h_0 = hh0=hh_0 = hh0​=h, the second equation is off by a difference of h_0 \delta _C h_0h0δCh0h_0 \delta _C h_0h0​δC​h0​. We simply add this as a correction term, h_1 = h_0 + \alpha h_0 \delta _C h_0h1=h0+αh0δCh0h_1 = h_0 + \alpha h_0 \delta _C h_0h1​=h0​+αh0​δC​h0​ where \alphaα\alphaα is some coefficient. (Note that essentially the only terms we can consider are of the form h_0 \delta _C h_0 \delta _C \cdots h_0h0δCh0δC⋯h0h_0 \delta _C h_0 \delta _C \cdots h_0h0​δC​h0​δC​⋯h0​, since nothing else has the same type.) We still have h_1 \circ h_1 = 0h1∘h1=0h_1 \circ h_1 = 0h1​∘h1​=0, and for the second equation this creates a new error term \begin {aligned} & \quad h_1 (d_C + \delta _C) h_1 - h_1 \\ &= (1 + \alpha ) h_0 \delta _C h_0 + 2 ( \alpha + \alpha ^2) h_0 \delta _C h_0 \delta _C h_0 + \alpha ^2 h_0 \delta _C h_0 \delta _C h_0 \delta _C h_0 \end {aligned}h1(dC+δC)h1−h1=(1+α)h0δCh0+2(α+α2)h0δCh0δCh0+α2h0δCh0δCh0δCh0\begin {aligned} & \quad h_1 (d_C + \delta _C) h_1 - h_1 \\ &= (1 + \alpha ) h_0 \delta _C h_0 + 2 ( \alpha + \alpha ^2) h_0 \delta _C h_0 \delta _C h_0 + \alpha ^2 h_0 \delta _C h_0 \delta _C h_0 \delta _C h_0 \end {aligned}​h1​(dC​+δC​)h1​−h1​=(1+α)h0​δC​h0​+2(α+α2)h0​δC​h0​δC​h0​+α2h0​δC​h0​δC​h0​δC​h0​​ and we can eliminate the first and second order part by setting \alpha = -1α=−1\alpha = -1α=−1. The natural next step would be to add a further correction h_2 = h_1 + \beta h_0 \delta _C h_0 \delta _C h_0h2=h1+βh0δCh0δCh0h_2 = h_1 + \beta h_0 \delta _C h_0 \delta _C h_0h2​=h1​+βh0​δC​h0​δC​h0​. This turns out to require \beta = +1β=+1\beta = +1β=+1, and so on.

From the informal discussion above, we can conjecture the formula h' = \sum _{k=0}^ \infty (-1)^k (h \delta _C)^k h.h′=∑k=0∞(−1)k(hδC)kh.h' = \sum _{k=0}^ \infty (-1)^k (h \delta _C)^k h.h′=k=0∑∞​(−1)k(hδC​)kh. This reveals the reason for our pointwise nilpotency condition. With a little bit of care manipulating the infinite sum, we can prove that h' \circ h' = 0h′∘h′=0h' \circ h' = 0h′∘h′=0 from h \circ h = 0h∘h=0h \circ h = 0h∘h=0, and the second equation follows from a nice telescopic sum \begin {aligned} h' \circ (d_C + \delta _C) \circ h' &= \sum _{i, j} (-1)^{i + j} (h \delta _C)^i h (d_C + \delta _C) (h \delta _C)^j h \\ &= \sum _{i, j} (-1)^{i + j} \left [(h \delta _C)^{i + j + 1} h + (h \delta _C)^{i + j} h \right ] \\ &= \sum _{k} (k+1) (-1)^k \left [(h \delta _C)^{k + 1} h + (h \delta _C)^k h \right ] \\ &= \sum _k (-1)^k (h \delta _C)^k h = h'. \end {aligned}h′∘(dC+δC)∘h′=∑i,j(−1)i+j(hδC)ih(dC+δC)(hδC)jh=∑i,j(−1)i+j[(hδC)i+j+1h+(hδC)i+jh]=∑k(k+1)(−1)k[(hδC)k+1h+(hδC)kh]=∑k(−1)k(hδC)kh=h′.\begin {aligned} h' \circ (d_C + \delta _C) \circ h' &= \sum _{i, j} (-1)^{i + j} (h \delta _C)^i h (d_C + \delta _C) (h \delta _C)^j h \\ &= \sum _{i, j} (-1)^{i + j} \left [(h \delta _C)^{i + j + 1} h + (h \delta _C)^{i + j} h \right ] \\ &= \sum _{k} (k+1) (-1)^k \left [(h \delta _C)^{k + 1} h + (h \delta _C)^k h \right ] \\ &= \sum _k (-1)^k (h \delta _C)^k h = h'. \end {aligned}h′∘(dC​+δC​)∘h′​=i,j∑​(−1)i+j(hδC​)ih(dC​+δC​)(hδC​)jh=i,j∑​(−1)i+j[(hδC​)i+j+1h+(hδC​)i+jh]=k∑​(k+1)(−1)k[(hδC​)k+1h+(hδC​)kh]=k∑​(−1)k(hδC​)kh=h′.​

We can reconstruct the other two components of the reduction \iota _{ \rho ' }ιρ′\iota _{ \rho ' }ιρ′​ and \pi _{ \rho ' }πρ′\pi _{ \rho ' }πρ′​ through . In particular, D'D′D'D′ is given by a perturbation of DDDD. We only write down the results below for easy reference. \begin {aligned} \pi _{ \rho ' } &= \sum _{k=0}^ \infty (-1)^k \pi _{ \rho } ( \delta _C h_{ \rho } )^k \\ \iota _{ \rho ' } &= \sum _{k=0}^ \infty (-1)^k ( h_{ \rho } \delta _C)^k \iota _{ \rho } \\ \delta _D &= \sum _{k=0}^ \infty (-1)^k \pi _{ \rho } \delta _C ( h_{ \rho } \delta _C)^k \iota _{ \rho } . \end {aligned}πρ′=∑k=0∞(−1)kπρ(δChρ)kιρ′=∑k=0∞(−1)k(hρδC)kιρδD=∑k=0∞(−1)kπρδC(hρδC)kιρ.\begin {aligned} \pi _{ \rho ' } &= \sum _{k=0}^ \infty (-1)^k \pi _{ \rho } ( \delta _C h_{ \rho } )^k \\ \iota _{ \rho ' } &= \sum _{k=0}^ \infty (-1)^k ( h_{ \rho } \delta _C)^k \iota _{ \rho } \\ \delta _D &= \sum _{k=0}^ \infty (-1)^k \pi _{ \rho } \delta _C ( h_{ \rho } \delta _C)^k \iota _{ \rho } . \end {aligned}πρ′​ιρ′​δD​​=k=0∑∞​(−1)kπρ​(δC​hρ​)k=k=0∑∞​(−1)k(hρ​δC​)kιρ​=k=0∑∞​(−1)kπρ​δC​(hρ​δC​)kιρ​.​

The following data are equivalent: A chain reduction \rho : C \Rightarrow \mkern {-14mu} \Rightarrow Dρ:C⇒⇒D\rho : C \Rightarrow \mkern {-14mu} \Rightarrow Dρ:C⇒⇒D. A splitting C \cong D \oplus EC≅D⊕EC \cong D \oplus EC≅D⊕E, where EEEE is a split exact. A chain homotopy h : C \to Ch:C→Ch : C \to Ch:C→C satisfying h \circ h = 0h∘h=0h \circ h = 0h∘h=0 and h \circ d_C \circ h = hh∘dC∘h=hh \circ d_C \circ h = hh∘dC​∘h=h.

A chain reduction consists of maps C_k \mathrel { \smash { \xtofrom [g_k]{f_k}}} D_kCk⇄gkfkDkC_k \mathrel { \smash { \xtofrom [g_k]{f_k}}} D_kCk​fk​gk​​Dk​ such that f_k \circ g_k = \operatorname {id}fk∘gk=id⁡f_k \circ g_k = \operatorname {id}fk​∘gk​=id. Therefore C_ \bulletC∙C_ \bulletC∙​ splits as D_ \bullet \oplus E_ \bulletD∙⊕E∙D_ \bullet \oplus E_ \bulletD∙​⊕E∙​, and the boundary maps are preserved since f, gf,gf, gf,g are chain maps. We have a homotopy h_k : D_k \oplus E_k \to D_{k+1} \oplus E_{k+1}hk:Dk⊕Ek→Dk+1⊕Ek+1h_k : D_k \oplus E_k \to D_{k+1} \oplus E_{k+1}hk​:Dk​⊕Ek​→Dk+1​⊕Ek+1​, which we may write as a (2 \times 2)(2×2)(2 \times 2)(2×2)-matrix. f \circ h = 0f∘h=0f \circ h = 0f∘h=0 demands the first row to be zero, and h \circ g = 0h∘g=0h \circ g = 0h∘g=0 requires the first column to vanish. This leaves us with \begin {bmatrix} 0 & 0 \\ 0 & r_k \end {bmatrix}[000rk]\begin {bmatrix} 0 & 0 \\ 0 & r_k \end {bmatrix}[00​0rk​​] such that r_{k+1} \circ r_k = 0rk+1∘rk=0r_{k+1} \circ r_k = 0rk+1​∘rk​=0, since h \circ h = 0h∘h=0h \circ h = 0h∘h=0.

Substituting the requirement that hhhh is a homotopy \operatorname {id} \to g \circ fid⁡→g∘f\operatorname {id} \to g \circ fid→g∘f, we get the equation d_{k+1} \circ r_k + r_{k-1} \circ d_k = \operatorname {id} ,dk+1∘rk+rk−1∘dk=id⁡,d_{k+1} \circ r_k + r_{k-1} \circ d_k = \operatorname {id} ,dk+1​∘rk​+rk−1​∘dk​=id, where dddd is the boundary operator on E_ \bulletE∙E_ \bulletE∙​. In other words, rrrr is a null-homotopy of E_ \bulletE∙E_ \bulletE∙​, rendering it split exact. Conversely, given C \cong D \oplus EC≅D⊕EC \cong D \oplus EC≅D⊕E, we can reconstruct ffff and gggg as the projection and inclusion maps, with hhhh obtained out of rrrr in the manner depicted above.

On the other hand, given only the homotopy operator, we expect to have d \circ h + h \circ d = \operatorname {id} - g \circ fd∘h+h∘d=id⁡−g∘fd \circ h + h \circ d = \operatorname {id} - g \circ fd∘h+h∘d=id−g∘f. And since g \circ fg∘fg \circ fg∘f should be the projector of CCCC onto the subspace DDDD, \operatorname {id} - g \circ fid⁡−g∘f\operatorname {id} - g \circ fid−g∘f should be the projector onto EEEE. We are thus led to proving p = d \circ h + h \circ dp=d∘h+h∘dp = d \circ h + h \circ dp=d∘h+h∘d is indeed a projector. \begin {aligned} p_k \circ p_k &= (d_{k+1} \circ h_k + h_{k-1} \circ d_k) \circ (d_{k+1} \circ h_k + h_{k-1} \circ d_k) \\ &= d_{k+1} \circ \overbrace {h_k \circ d_{k+1} \circ h_k}^{h_k} + d_{k+1} \circ \overbrace {h_k \circ h_{k-1}}^{0} \circ d_k \\ & \qquad + h_{k-1} \circ \underbrace {d_k \circ d_{k+1}}_{0} \circ h_k + \underbrace {h_{k-1} \circ d_k \circ h_{k-1}}_{h_{k-1}} \circ d_k \\ &= d_{k+1} \circ h_k + h_{k-1} \circ d_k = p_k. \end {aligned}pk∘pk=(dk+1∘hk+hk−1∘dk)∘(dk+1∘hk+hk−1∘dk)=dk+1∘hk∘dk+1∘hk⏞hk+dk+1∘hk∘hk−1⏞0∘dk+hk−1∘dk∘dk+1⏟0∘hk+hk−1∘dk∘hk−1⏟hk−1∘dk=dk+1∘hk+hk−1∘dk=pk.\begin {aligned} p_k \circ p_k &= (d_{k+1} \circ h_k + h_{k-1} \circ d_k) \circ (d_{k+1} \circ h_k + h_{k-1} \circ d_k) \\ &= d_{k+1} \circ \overbrace {h_k \circ d_{k+1} \circ h_k}^{h_k} + d_{k+1} \circ \overbrace {h_k \circ h_{k-1}}^{0} \circ d_k \\ & \qquad + h_{k-1} \circ \underbrace {d_k \circ d_{k+1}}_{0} \circ h_k + \underbrace {h_{k-1} \circ d_k \circ h_{k-1}}_{h_{k-1}} \circ d_k \\ &= d_{k+1} \circ h_k + h_{k-1} \circ d_k = p_k. \end {aligned}pk​∘pk​​=(dk+1​∘hk​+hk−1​∘dk​)∘(dk+1​∘hk​+hk−1​∘dk​)=dk+1​∘hk​∘dk+1​∘hk​​hk​​+dk+1​∘hk​∘hk−1​​0​∘dk​+hk−1​∘0dk​∘dk+1​​​∘hk​+hk−1​hk−1​∘dk​∘hk−1​​​∘dk​=dk+1​∘hk​+hk−1​∘dk​=pk​.​ Therefore we conclude that p_kpkp_kpk​ splits C_k \cong D_k \oplus E_kCk≅Dk⊕EkC_k \cong D_k \oplus E_kCk​≅Dk​⊕Ek​. More over, p \circ d = d \circ h \circ d = d \circ pp∘d=d∘h∘d=d∘pp \circ d = d \circ h \circ d = d \circ pp∘d=d∘h∘d=d∘p, meaning pppp is a chain map, and therefore the splitting is compatible with the boundary operator. Since h \circ p = p \circ h = h \circ d \circ h = hh∘p=p∘h=h∘d∘h=hh \circ p = p \circ h = h \circ d \circ h = hh∘p=p∘h=h∘d∘h=h, the homotopy is also compatible with the splitting, so we can restrict it onto E_kEkE_kEk​ to get a homotopy from \operatorname {id} _Eid⁡E\operatorname {id} _EidE​ to 0000.

Finally, restricting hhhh onto D_kDkD_kDk​ we see that it must be zero, since h( \operatorname {id} - p) = h - h \circ d \circ h = 0h(id⁡−p)=h−h∘d∘h=0h( \operatorname {id} - p) = h - h \circ d \circ h = 0h(id−p)=h−h∘d∘h=0. This means that all the information of hhhh can be reconstructed from the splitting, and thus all three sets of data are equivalent.

frontmatter.title: Perturbation of the smaller chain complex in a chain reduction

mainmatter.p: Given a reduction \rho : C \Rightarrow \mkern {-14mu} \Rightarrow Dρ:C⇒⇒D\rho : C \Rightarrow \mkern {-14mu} \Rightarrow Dρ:C⇒⇒D and a perturbation \delta _DδD\delta _DδD​ for DDDD, we can construct a perturbation \delta _CδC\delta _CδC​ for CCCC, such that the same \rhoρ\rhoρ can serve as a reduction of the perturbed chain complexes.

Let the reduction \rhoρ\rhoρ be made out of the three maps \pi _{ \rho } : C \to Dπρ:C→D\pi _{ \rho } : C \to Dπρ​:C→D, \iota _{ \rho } : D \to Cιρ:D→C\iota _{ \rho } : D \to Cιρ​:D→C and h_{ \rho } : C \to Chρ:C→Ch_{ \rho } : C \to Chρ​:C→C. Then since CCCC splits as the direct sum of DDDD and an acyclic complex, we can simply copy over the perturbation, and leave the acyclic part untouched. This gives us the definition \delta _C = \iota _{ \rho } \circ \delta _D \circ \pi _{ \rho }δC=ιρ∘δD∘πρ\delta _C = \iota _{ \rho } \circ \delta _D \circ \pi _{ \rho }δC​=ιρ​∘δD​∘πρ​. A quick computation shows that \rhoρ\rhoρ is still a reduction of the perturbed chain complexes.

Given two chain complexes C, DC,DC, DC,D, a chain reduction consists of a chain map \pi : C \to Dπ:C→D\pi : C \to Dπ:C→D, a chain map \iota : D \to Cι:D→C\iota : D \to Cι:D→C and a chain homotopy h : \operatorname {id} \to g \circ fh:id⁡→g∘fh : \operatorname {id} \to g \circ fh:id→g∘f, such that \pi \circ \iota = \operatorname {id}π∘ι=id⁡\pi \circ \iota = \operatorname {id}π∘ι=id, and \pi \circ h = h \circ \iota = h \circ h = 0.π∘h=h∘ι=h∘h=0.\pi \circ h = h \circ \iota = h \circ h = 0.π∘h=h∘ι=h∘h=0. Here the compositions are understood to have the appropriate subscript so the degrees match.

We write the reduction as \rho : C \Rightarrow \mkern {-14mu} \Rightarrow Dρ:C⇒⇒D\rho : C \Rightarrow \mkern {-14mu} \Rightarrow Dρ:C⇒⇒D. The three components are denoted \pi _{ \rho } : C \to Dπρ:C→D\pi _{ \rho } : C \to Dπρ​:C→D, \iota _{ \rho } : D \to Cιρ:D→C\iota _{ \rho } : D \to Cιρ​:D→C and h_{ \rho } : C \to Chρ:C→Ch_{ \rho } : C \to Chρ​:C→C, respectively.

frontmatter.title: Perturbation of the larger chain complex in a chain reduction

mainmatter.p: Given a reduction \rho : C \Rightarrow \mkern {-14mu} \Rightarrow Dρ:C⇒⇒D\rho : C \Rightarrow \mkern {-14mu} \Rightarrow Dρ:C⇒⇒D and a perturbation \delta _CδC\delta _CδC​ for CCCC, we assume that h_{ \rho } \circ \delta _Chρ∘δCh_{ \rho } \circ \delta _Chρ​∘δC​ is pointwise nilpotent, i.e. \forall c \in C_k, \exists n \in \mathbb {N}, \; ( h_{ \rho } \delta _C)^n (c) = 0.∀c∈Ck,∃n∈N,  (hρδC)n(c)=0.\forall c \in C_k, \exists n \in \mathbb {N}, \; ( h_{ \rho } \delta _C)^n (c) = 0.∀c∈Ck​,∃n∈N,(hρ​δC​)n(c)=0. We can construct a new chain reduction \rho ' : C' \Rightarrow \mkern {-14mu} \Rightarrow D'ρ′:C′⇒⇒D′\rho ' : C' \Rightarrow \mkern {-14mu} \Rightarrow D'ρ′:C′⇒⇒D′, where C'C′C'C′ is CCCC perturbed by \delta _CδC\delta _CδC​.
Note that this situation is much harder compared to , as it is generally impossible without the added condition.

For this construction using the third equivalent definition of a chain reduction in , i.e. a homotopy operator on CCCC such that h \circ h = 0h∘h=0h \circ h = 0h∘h=0 and h \circ d_C \circ h = hh∘dC∘h=hh \circ d_C \circ h = hh∘dC​∘h=h.

We need to construct a new homotopy operator such that h' \circ h' = 0h′∘h′=0h' \circ h' = 0h′∘h′=0 and h' \circ (d_C + \delta _C) \circ h' = h'h′∘(dC+δC)∘h′=h′h' \circ (d_C + \delta _C) \circ h' = h'h′∘(dC​+δC​)∘h′=h′. We approach this through a “perturbative” mindset. Starting with h_0 = hh0=hh_0 = hh0​=h, the second equation is off by a difference of h_0 \delta _C h_0h0δCh0h_0 \delta _C h_0h0​δC​h0​. We simply add this as a correction term, h_1 = h_0 + \alpha h_0 \delta _C h_0h1=h0+αh0δCh0h_1 = h_0 + \alpha h_0 \delta _C h_0h1​=h0​+αh0​δC​h0​ where \alphaα\alphaα is some coefficient. (Note that essentially the only terms we can consider are of the form h_0 \delta _C h_0 \delta _C \cdots h_0h0δCh0δC⋯h0h_0 \delta _C h_0 \delta _C \cdots h_0h0​δC​h0​δC​⋯h0​, since nothing else has the same type.) We still have h_1 \circ h_1 = 0h1∘h1=0h_1 \circ h_1 = 0h1​∘h1​=0, and for the second equation this creates a new error term \begin {aligned} & \quad h_1 (d_C + \delta _C) h_1 - h_1 \\ &= (1 + \alpha ) h_0 \delta _C h_0 + 2 ( \alpha + \alpha ^2) h_0 \delta _C h_0 \delta _C h_0 + \alpha ^2 h_0 \delta _C h_0 \delta _C h_0 \delta _C h_0 \end {aligned}h1(dC+δC)h1−h1=(1+α)h0δCh0+2(α+α2)h0δCh0δCh0+α2h0δCh0δCh0δCh0\begin {aligned} & \quad h_1 (d_C + \delta _C) h_1 - h_1 \\ &= (1 + \alpha ) h_0 \delta _C h_0 + 2 ( \alpha + \alpha ^2) h_0 \delta _C h_0 \delta _C h_0 + \alpha ^2 h_0 \delta _C h_0 \delta _C h_0 \delta _C h_0 \end {aligned}​h1​(dC​+δC​)h1​−h1​=(1+α)h0​δC​h0​+2(α+α2)h0​δC​h0​δC​h0​+α2h0​δC​h0​δC​h0​δC​h0​​ and we can eliminate the first and second order part by setting \alpha = -1α=−1\alpha = -1α=−1. The natural next step would be to add a further correction h_2 = h_1 + \beta h_0 \delta _C h_0 \delta _C h_0h2=h1+βh0δCh0δCh0h_2 = h_1 + \beta h_0 \delta _C h_0 \delta _C h_0h2​=h1​+βh0​δC​h0​δC​h0​. This turns out to require \beta = +1β=+1\beta = +1β=+1, and so on.

From the informal discussion above, we can conjecture the formula h' = \sum _{k=0}^ \infty (-1)^k (h \delta _C)^k h.h′=∑k=0∞(−1)k(hδC)kh.h' = \sum _{k=0}^ \infty (-1)^k (h \delta _C)^k h.h′=k=0∑∞​(−1)k(hδC​)kh. This reveals the reason for our pointwise nilpotency condition. With a little bit of care manipulating the infinite sum, we can prove that h' \circ h' = 0h′∘h′=0h' \circ h' = 0h′∘h′=0 from h \circ h = 0h∘h=0h \circ h = 0h∘h=0, and the second equation follows from a nice telescopic sum \begin {aligned} h' \circ (d_C + \delta _C) \circ h' &= \sum _{i, j} (-1)^{i + j} (h \delta _C)^i h (d_C + \delta _C) (h \delta _C)^j h \\ &= \sum _{i, j} (-1)^{i + j} \left [(h \delta _C)^{i + j + 1} h + (h \delta _C)^{i + j} h \right ] \\ &= \sum _{k} (k+1) (-1)^k \left [(h \delta _C)^{k + 1} h + (h \delta _C)^k h \right ] \\ &= \sum _k (-1)^k (h \delta _C)^k h = h'. \end {aligned}h′∘(dC+δC)∘h′=∑i,j(−1)i+j(hδC)ih(dC+δC)(hδC)jh=∑i,j(−1)i+j[(hδC)i+j+1h+(hδC)i+jh]=∑k(k+1)(−1)k[(hδC)k+1h+(hδC)kh]=∑k(−1)k(hδC)kh=h′.\begin {aligned} h' \circ (d_C + \delta _C) \circ h' &= \sum _{i, j} (-1)^{i + j} (h \delta _C)^i h (d_C + \delta _C) (h \delta _C)^j h \\ &= \sum _{i, j} (-1)^{i + j} \left [(h \delta _C)^{i + j + 1} h + (h \delta _C)^{i + j} h \right ] \\ &= \sum _{k} (k+1) (-1)^k \left [(h \delta _C)^{k + 1} h + (h \delta _C)^k h \right ] \\ &= \sum _k (-1)^k (h \delta _C)^k h = h'. \end {aligned}h′∘(dC​+δC​)∘h′​=i,j∑​(−1)i+j(hδC​)ih(dC​+δC​)(hδC​)jh=i,j∑​(−1)i+j[(hδC​)i+j+1h+(hδC​)i+jh]=k∑​(k+1)(−1)k[(hδC​)k+1h+(hδC​)kh]=k∑​(−1)k(hδC​)kh=h′.​

We can reconstruct the other two components of the reduction \iota _{ \rho ' }ιρ′\iota _{ \rho ' }ιρ′​ and \pi _{ \rho ' }πρ′\pi _{ \rho ' }πρ′​ through . In particular, D'D′D'D′ is given by a perturbation of DDDD. We only write down the results below for easy reference. \begin {aligned} \pi _{ \rho ' } &= \sum _{k=0}^ \infty (-1)^k \pi _{ \rho } ( \delta _C h_{ \rho } )^k \\ \iota _{ \rho ' } &= \sum _{k=0}^ \infty (-1)^k ( h_{ \rho } \delta _C)^k \iota _{ \rho } \\ \delta _D &= \sum _{k=0}^ \infty (-1)^k \pi _{ \rho } \delta _C ( h_{ \rho } \delta _C)^k \iota _{ \rho } . \end {aligned}πρ′=∑k=0∞(−1)kπρ(δChρ)kιρ′=∑k=0∞(−1)k(hρδC)kιρδD=∑k=0∞(−1)kπρδC(hρδC)kιρ.\begin {aligned} \pi _{ \rho ' } &= \sum _{k=0}^ \infty (-1)^k \pi _{ \rho } ( \delta _C h_{ \rho } )^k \\ \iota _{ \rho ' } &= \sum _{k=0}^ \infty (-1)^k ( h_{ \rho } \delta _C)^k \iota _{ \rho } \\ \delta _D &= \sum _{k=0}^ \infty (-1)^k \pi _{ \rho } \delta _C ( h_{ \rho } \delta _C)^k \iota _{ \rho } . \end {aligned}πρ′​ιρ′​δD​​=k=0∑∞​(−1)kπρ​(δC​hρ​)k=k=0∑∞​(−1)k(hρ​δC​)kιρ​=k=0∑∞​(−1)kπρ​δC​(hρ​δC​)kιρ​.​

authors.author: Julio Rubio García and Francis Sergeraert

mainmatter.p: This text was written and used for a MAP Summer School at the University of Genova, August 28 to September 2, 2006. Available since then on the web site of the second author, it has been used and referenced by several colleagues working in Commutative Algebra and Algebraic Topology. To make safer such references, it was suggested to place it on the Arxiv repository. It is a relatively detailed exposition of the use of the Basic Perturbation Lemma to make constructive Homological Algebra (standard Homological Algebra is not constructive) and how this technology can be used in Commutative Algebra (Koszul complexes) and Algebraic Topology (effective versions of spectral sequences).
